I loved October Sky. The thing I loved most had to be the music. It worked two ways: in the first hour of the film, it gives us a sense of era - both rural West Virginia and outer-space-aspiring son-of-a-coal-miner rather than from-outer-space (this is done even better with Columbite-Tantalite), and then cool lovesongs from listening-tunes era after each big mining accident love-letter or headline news reporter interview scene

I first saw this one when it was first shown, so I'm not too objective about it. It really managed to scare me, partly because it was a fairly simple, gritty little ride. Live action is tough to pull off in the horror genre with special effects these days.
The lack of a happy ending is also refreshing and bears mentioning that good 'ol pent up revenge makes for some sadistic fun.
Still ranks amongst my favorites after all these years.<|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|>

Latter Days is a very, VERY independent movie. And compared to many of today's more modern films, it's lacking on many parts. The shooting budget was very cheap and the overall movie has an amateurish quality to it most times (though visually pleasing as well). But yet I still found myself eagerly watching every frame of this rather long one-man production. Very much in the same vain as Christopher Guest has become successful at doing with films like A Might Wind...D

This is a fine musical with a timeless score by one of my favorite composers (Gershwin) and a nice 'Parisien' atmosphere which gives the Bostonians, well Bostonians, an exotic wonderland , where they can behave as if they were Parisian. Okay. Here's the thing. Well I don't know much about anything, but I sure liked this film. In short, it was creative, humorous, simple, and heartwarming.
I could tell that the people working behind the scenes really cared about their film. They may not be professionals by trade or taste (possibly possible), but they went above and beyond to make a wonderful short film.
The story is simple, there is no need to explain it. Nothing too deep with love lost or anything
